The claim is supported by a study publis: titled "Violent Death Rates: The US Compared with Other High-income OECD Countries, 2010." The study used mortality data from 2010 collected by the World Health Organization to compare gun homicide rates in the United States with 22 other populous and high-income countries.
The study found that the rate of gun hom: 2 times higher than in the other countries included in the analysis. This data supports the claim that Americans are 25 times more likely to be shot and killed than individuals in developed countries.
The study also revealed that when consid: including homicides, accidental shootings, and suicides, people in the United States were 10 times more likely to die from a gun-related death compared to those in the other countries.
An expert: David Hemenway, professor of health policy at the Harvard School of Public Health and co-author of the study, supported the claim and stated that anyone who looks at the data would agree that the claim is accurate.
